data.title: Caterpillar: Sell The AI Exuberance
data.description:
As you can see in the chart below, I have been bearish on Caterpillar Inc. (CAT) this year. By now, it appears that I've likely missed something as the stock has rallied ~40% since my latest article. In that analysis I found signs that tariffs were wreaking havoc on the company's profitability and with the valuation being elevated I thought the risk/reward was unattractive. Caterpillar seems to have found a new catalyst: AI.

In the analysis below, it is shown that AI is powering strong results in their Energy & Transportation segment. While that's great news, tariff headwinds are alive and well. Profitability was significantly eroded with operating profit and EPS both declining YoY despite good demand. While there should be some optimism as a result of AI tailwinds, I believe the forward P/E's rapid expansion since the middle of the year shows that there has been too much exuberance with no easy fix for the company's profitability woes. The stock trades at a hefty premium and since there seems to be overvaluation, I have decided to stick with my sell rating for now.

Demand Is Picking Up

Caterpillar reported 2025 Q3 earnings just very recently on October 29th and top-line results show signs that demand is starting to pick up. We'll go into more depth regarding where this strength is coming from a bit later but for Q3, the company as a whole reported sales and revenues of $17.638 billion. This is a fresh all-time record for Caterpillar and it represents growth of 10% YoY. That is a major bounce back after a 1% decline in sales and revenues in their Q2 and so business activity has taken a major turn for the better.

In addition, they smashed consensus expectations as they beat them by a whopping $864.15 million. Even for a company of their size, that is a substantial beat and so their top line was a pleasant surprise for sure. In the above chart you can see that sales volume was the major driver for growth, again indicating that business activity has improved significantly. There was some minor weakness in price realization that may be an indication of an unfavorable mix but the effects are really negligible when compared to the considerable increase in volume. Lastly, as another sign that demand is becoming robust, Caterpillar reported that their backlog has hit $39.8 billion, a fresh all-time record. Of course, this is welcome news for investors.

Energy & Transportation

As promised, let's see where all the top-line strength is coming from. Their Energy & Transportation segment is currently their largest segment both by sales and profit and in Q3, it saw by far the strongest results. This is the segment that's directly involved with AI since AI data centers use Caterpillar's battery storage systems and backup generators. I, for one, did not foresee AI providing significant tailwinds to their business but here we are and it really acts as a saviour to the company.

As you can see above, total sales jumped by 17% YoY as they reported strong sales volume. Their Construction segment saw growth of just 7% while their Resource segment had just 2% growth. The importance of their Energy & Transport segment doesn't end there, however. While profit margin expanded by 10 basis points in this segment, the other two segments saw considerable margin contraction and so in addition to driving top-line growth, AI tailwinds seem to be doing the heavy lifting in terms of the company's profitability. Overall, with AI data center construction showing no signs of slowing down, Caterpillar seems well-positioned to continue benefitting.

Tariffs Still A Headwind

In the above chart, the factors affecting operating profit are shown. Despite a healthy growth rate for the top line, operating profit actually fell 3% YoY to $3.052 billion. As you can see, the sales volume strength and price realization weakness carried over from their sales and revenues figures but the main cause of profitability weakness was due to manufacturing costs. In their earnings release, Caterpillar stated that "unfavorable manufacturing costs largely reflected the impact of higher tariffs." This shows that despite the AI tailwinds they are benefitting from, the tariff headwinds that I highlighted in my previous article are still alive and well. If it weren't for the margin strength in their Energy & Transportation segment, things could have been much worse for their profits.

Speaking of profits, Caterpillar reported an adjusted EPS of $4.95 for Q3, representing a 4.26% decline YoY. While that's still undesirable, do note that in Q2, they experienced a 21.2% decline for EPS and so there has been notable improvement. In addition, they managed to beat expectations by $0.43 to show outperformance and so despite the YoY decline, results were still better than feared.

Cash Flows & Capital Returns

Despite the profitability weakness, Caterpillar managed a nice improvement in cash flows. The company reported ME&T free cash flows of $3.2 billion, representing an ~$500 million increase over the prior year period. While this is, of course, good news, shareholders may not be too thrilled that capital returns actually dropped YoY.

In Q3, Caterpillar distributed a total of $1.1 billion, ~$700 million in the form of dividends and ~$400 million in the form of share repurchases. While total dividend payout remained relatively stable from the year-ago quarter, stock buybacks dropped significantly YoY from ~$800 million. Therefore, while FCFs improved, the company doesn't seem too eager to share the cash with shareholders. That could be a sign of cautiousness from management.

Outlook

Caterpillar provided limited numeric financial guidance but still gave some broad ideas of how the outlook is shaping up. For full year 2025, they now expect sales and revenues to be modestly higher than in 2024. This is a change in language from "slightly higher" and so in essence, they have raised their guidance. For Q4 in particular, they are expecting "strong" sales and revenue growth and so it appears that the AI tailwinds are indeed going to continue for their Energy & Transportation business.

With or without tariff effects included, Caterpillar expects the full-year adjusted operating profit margin to be in their annual target range. However, without tariffs, the figure would be in the top half of the range while with tariffs, the figure would be in the bottom half. Therefore, for 2025 as a whole, tariffs will be a significant drag on the company's profitability. Overall, I would say there are not many surprises in their outlook as the AI boost to sales and profitability weakness were already seen in their Q3.

Investors May Be Overoptimistic

As you can see in the chart above, Caterpillar's forward P/E ratio has been in a quite steady uptrend over the past few years. Since the middle of this year, it seems the expansion has picked up speed, and I believe the current reading of 31.45 shows excessive optimism.

Firstly, investors should definitely cheer the arrival of AI tailwinds. I, personally, did not foresee AI data centers having such a profound impact on their Energy & Transportation business and so it's a pleasant surprise. However, the company is not out of the woods. Growth in their other two segments is still relatively sluggish and more importantly tariffs are weighing heavily on profitability. It is unlikely to be an easy fix for profitability as tariffs are really beyond the control of Caterpillar and so while overall demand is back on a good trajectory, headwinds are eroding that positivity as seen by the decline in operating profit and EPS.

Therefore, I believe investors who are piling into the stock due to the new association with AI have become overoptimistic regarding their outlook. Note that Seeking Alpha shows the stock is trading at a nearly 50% premium to the Industrials sector according to the non-GAAP forward P/E ratio. Therefore, I would be very cautious about the current valuation.

Concluding Remarks

While there are some good signs for Caterpillar, in my view investors have gotten ahead of themselves. The elephant in the room was the big boost provided by AI tailwinds but while many are focusing on the resulting improved demand, I believe overlooking the profitability woes would be a mistake. Despite all the optimism, the company's profits actually shrank YoY due to tariffs and with no easy fix to this issue, I would say the outlook is still only mixed. Meanwhile, as shown above, the forward P/E has roared to a multiyear high and is at a major premium to the sector. I believe this shows investors have become a bit too exuberant on the stock. With Caterpillar being overvalued, I have decided to maintain my sell rating at this point.

data.title: Infineon Is Attractive Again After Q3 2025 And Going Into Q4 (Rating Upgrade)
data.description:
Infineon (OTCQX:IFNNY)(OTCQX:IFNNF) is one of the world's leading companies in semiconductors and chips. It has, for the longest time, been my choice of investment in this sector thanks to superb fundamentals and overall very solid trends. Furthermore, unlike many of its peers, it has not been suffering from excessive or overly high valuation levels. This has made the company, when it's attractively valued, my #1 choice. In the past 2 years, I have added to the company, but I went neutral on Infineon after it went too high a few months ago, back in the summer. The company has, since that article that you can find here, reported 3Q25 and is within 2-4 weeks of reporting 4Q25.

Because of that, this article will focus on 2 things.

First, provide a look at where Infineon is today and what makes the company potentially investable, now that it's down (as I expected) from the price when I last covered it.

Secondly, to provide you with a preview of 4Q25, my forecasts, and what I expect the company to be able to manage for the full year, as well as for 2027-2028.

The valuation for this company makes sense to me, unlike many of its peers that trade at multiples twice or even thrice as high as Infineon.

Generally, analysts have been positive since 3Q25. So am I. The company has declined despite what I believe to be a significant improvement in prospects and also somewhat in fundamentals.

Let's look at what we have here.

Plenty to like, even if the valuation isn't as great

Infineon is, in large part, a play on things like automotive chip/semiconductor markets. That means if you're bearish or not excessively bullish on the EV trends currently permeating the market, you should (like me) take a somewhat more conservative stance on the company and its potential. Not that it's going to go negative or anything - just not as bullish as some perhaps tend to be.

It's wrong, however, to say it's "just" EVs. Even the new generation of ICE vehicles needs all manner of sensors - voltage chips and the like, which are supplied by a market leader like Infineon. As I've mentioned earlier, the company is a great player in power efficiency in general, and if you notice what industries across the world are doing, power conservation is definitely part of this.

High-level risks to a legacy, Europe-located company such as this are very macro-oriented. We could mention the fact that China seems very set on developing its own chip industry in the country, but this also needs consideration that Infineon is actually a business that focuses on discrete power, rather than analog power management ICs.

So what the heck is the difference?

Well, the former, which is Infineon's focus, are things like transistors and resistors - while the latter are things like so-called PMICs, that combine functions in a single "die". Discrete power solutions, therefore, have the option of handling flexibility, but they are more complex to design. This inherent complexity of what Infineon does effectively acts like a very good moat against other companies.

It's one of the core reasons I like investing in it.

The drawback of this, and the drawbacks of Infineon in its current structure, is that the company's products offer less margin advantage and pricing power relative to the other category. Also, it forces Infineon to have manufacturing capacity different from its peers, leading to higher fixed costs in a scenario where supply exceeds demand. Because much of the demand comes from the automotive industry, this means that you should be prepared for volatility. Infineon has actually, as of the last few years, focused more on its automotive and industrial sectors, essentially increasing its exposure to that volatility in turn (divesting smaller business parts).

And while arguments in its favor are healthy growth from increases in products from Infineon, both in ICE and EVs, there is a commodity characteristic to the business that is hard to get away from. Further, because of its exposure to the EU, the company doesn't have access to the advantages of low labor costs that other companies enjoy.

Nevertheless, the company performed very well during 3Q.

And while I've harped on the company's exposure to automotive, there's exposure to things like general e-mobility, renewables, software, IoT, AI and data that isn't to be underestimated either. Neither is the company's clearly market-leading position in its segments, which, despite some commodity characteristics, gives it price advantages.

The company's expectations for 2025 include sales revenues of over €14.5B with a gross margin of above 40%, and a result operating margin in the high teens, trending toward 20% over time, with an FCF of at least €1B per year. Infineon is going through a high investment period, with over €2B being allocated to investments at this time for 2025 alone.

The company's closest competitors are ON Semi, Texas Instruments (TXN), and STMicroelectronics (STM). I've covered both STM and ON - but aside from ON (which has a different risk profile) Infineon is probably the more attractive of these at this time - I'll show this to you in valuation. My point here is that for what the company does, there aren't that many significant players in the field, and Infineon is by far the biggest one.

With very solid 3Q25 results, and an estimate for 2025E fiscal that is sort of a "kitchen sink" year, Infineon is poised to see recovery and growth from the automotive trend shift that we've been able to slightly confirm with businesses like Autoliv (ALV) (albeit a slow trend shift).

The right way to invest in Infineon here is, I believe, for a 3-4 year timeframe. That's the time required to see growth materialize here, but once it does, we can see a significant and market-beating rate of return.

The last quarter of 2025E, which reports in about 2-3 weeks, is unlikely to change things here. While my expectation is for the company to return to growth in 4Q25 with demand recovery for its products, the YoY results for 2025E are likely to be negative to the tune of a double-digit EPS decline. Following 4Q, I expect a gradual improvement in results as the automotive sector recovers (step by step), a somewhat lower expectation than we've seen from its own forecasts.

The keyword here is "ongoing recovery", which I believe will happen in 2026-2028, the next 2 fiscal and calendar years.

It's hard to say whether the company's results, if they are as expected, will cause a decline or not, but I don't consider such a potential decline to be material enough to change my thesis or valuation.

Valuation - Recovery is coming, but may take 15-30 months

My PT was €35/share for Infineon in my last article. That PT still holds. The company is currently trading at €34.3. I considered raising my PT and fair value targets here, but ultimately decided that they still serve. However, I will make it clear here that once things start to grow, I will be raising the fair value and PT's to better reflect what I believe Infineon in a growth environment to be capable of, which is closer to a €50/share fair value at a 20x P/E for the 2028E fiscal, which would in turn imply a PT of about €42/share.

But this requires better results.

For now, buying at this valuation comes with a significant upside both to my previous fair value target of €38-€39/share, but also to a longer-term upside. The longer-term annualized RoR here is 15-16% per year at a 5-10 year average, and over 16% at the average 20-year P/E.

So, since my last article, Infineon has dropped to valuations I would consider investable here. The combination of upside from 2026-2028E from a recovering automotive market, with the relatively low valuation and the company currently being in a dip, implies this. The fundamentals are reflective of this as well, including a BBB+ credit rating, a 1% yield (low, but safe, and growing), very low debt at below 22% long-term debt/capital, and a market cap, even with the drop, of below €44B at this time.

Better alternatives with a similar risk profile are very rare at this time. You could make an argument for STMicroelectronics, which I've also made in a recent article where I covered the company. The upside is 15-17% here as well. I consider Infineon better than STM because of the depth of the EPS drop in STM; however, at this time it is expected to drop by over 60%. Infineon is, simply put, safer here.

Texas Instruments, meanwhile, is in a remarkably similar trend as this company, with the exception of no near-term crash (the crash for TXN was in 2024, not 2025, also at about 24%). The issue I have with TXN is the forward valuation premium. This company requires 23-25x P/E to outperform, at 20x P/E like Infineon, it's essentially 0% growth or thereabouts - negative without the impressive 3.5%+ dividend that the company pays.

Meanwhile, ON Semiconductor (ON) may be undervalued, but it is also incredibly volatile and currently has no yield. Its range in the last 52 weeks has been between $31 and $76, which should express the depth of that volatility. The company is also, out of these, the only one with a junk-graded investment rating, and at 15x P/E, the 20-year average, is set to give less than 15% annualized.

I therefore consider ON to be uninvestable here as well, with regard to my targets.

That brings alternatives to either STM or Infineon - and my choice here is Infineon.

Risks & Considerations

If Infineon were to significantly outperform and some risk factors were not to be as severe as expected, then price targets and fair values could go up to a €38/share or above mark, an attractive price target. Furthermore, historically, we've been able to see valuation levels of over 30x P/E, and if these come back, then the current valuation of 25x P/E is only the beginning. But as things currently stand, Infineon is set to recover as the automotive sector recovers.

Significant risks for the company at this valuation are more general in nature. Commoditization of its industry, lower gross margins than its peers, and cyclicality not only of semis, but of end industries can cause further volatility, and for the recovery to take longer than expected.

Beyond that, I do not view there to be many significant risks to my thesis and price target at this time.

Thesis

Infineon is a very solid business with a good long-term upside. It has sector leadership in multiple, crucial segments in the chip industry, and despite the commoditization of some of its end markets as well as the competitive position from China, I do not view it as unlikely that the company may outperform over the long term. In fact, I view it as likely, and this makes it a "Buy" at the right price.

I don't see anything in 3Q25 or the coming 4Q25 to change my thesis or expectation for the company from my assumption of buy, which leads me, as of this time, to increase my rating back to buy, and I maintain my previous PT of €35/share and fair value of €38-€39/share. Once we start seeing concrete recovery, I would increase this to allow for higher multiples.

Here are my criteria and how the company fulfills them (italicized).

  • This company is overall qualitative.

  • This company is fundamentally safe/conservative & well-run.

  • This company pays a well-covered dividend.

  • This company is currently cheap.

  • This company has a realistic upside based on earnings growth or multiple expansion/reversion.

The company fulfills 3 out of 3 quality indicators and 1 out of 2 valuation indicators. That means 4/5 "stars" here, which is enough for an attractive thesis for the company. Based on this, and a valuation target of €35/share, I see a risk/reward-adjusted upside that's attractive enough for me. I give the company a "Buy" rating as of October 2025, a rating change towards the higher.

Editor's Note: This article discusses one or more securities that do not trade on a major U.S. exchange. Please be aware of the risks associated with these stocks.

data.title: Commodities: OPEC+ Set For Another Supply Increase
data.description:
By Warren Patterson, Head of Commodities Strategy, and Ewa Manthey, Commodities Strategist

Energy - OPEC+ set to meet

The oil market is on track to settle lower this week as market participants digest the implications of US sanctions on Russian oil flows. Clearly, the price action suggests that the market is not convinced that we will lose a significant amount of Russian oil supply. Yesterday’s meeting between President Trump and President Xi only served to strengthen this conviction, with Russian oil flows to China apparently not part of broader talks between the two leaders. This is important for the market given that China imports around 2m b/d of Russian oil. It’s the only buyer that could meaningfully increase its purchases if India reduced its imports of Russian crude.

On Sunday, OPEC+ is set to meet. It appears likely that the group will agree to another 137k b/d supply increase for December. The uncertainty surrounding sanctions on Russia also supports this increase. However, the move will only reinforce the bearish outlook for the market, adding to the substantial surplus expected through 2026. Obviously, this is assuming no supply shocks from Russia.

Middle distillate cracks remain well-supported, with lingering uncertainty over the impact of sanctions on Russian diesel exports. The ICE gasoil crack is holding around $30/bbl, after a strong rally since mid-October. However, the latest data from Insights Global shows that gasoil inventories in the Amsterdam-Rotterdam-Antwerp (ARA) region increased by 109kt WoW to 2.27mt, which saw its gap to the 5-year average widen. In Singapore, meanwhile, after a significant increase in middle distillate stocks the previous week, stocks declined by 6.25m barrels over the last week.

US natural gas Dec’25 futures rallied 3.7% yesterday, and the strength has continued in early morning trading today. The move higher comes despite US natural gas inventories rising by 74 bcf over the last week, in line with expectations and above the 5-year average increase of 67 bcf. Instead, the market appears to be focused on forecasts for cooler weather, which should prove supportive of demand.

Agriculture - China to buy 25mt of US soybeans annually

CBOT soybean futures extended their upward rally, with prices surging more than 1.9% at one stage yesterday. This was after President Donald Trump announced that China would immediately purchase large volumes of US soybeans. Later, the US administration said that China agreed to buy 12mt of soybeans between now and January, with a further commitment to purchase at least 25mt annually over the next three years. The announced purchases are largely in line with China's imports of US soybeans prior to the trade war. For reference, China imported around 22mt of US soybeans in 2024.

The latest fortnightly report from the Brazilian Sugarcane and Bioenergy Industry Association (UNICA) shows that sugarcane crushing in Central-South Brazil stood at 34mt over the first half of October, an increase of 0.3% year-on-year. Sugar output over this period rose 1.25% YoY to 2.48mt. Meanwhile, the sugar mix in CS Brazil over the fortnight was 48.2%, up from 47.3% a year ago. This is despite prices suggesting that mills should favour a stronger ethanol mix. The cumulative cane crush so far this season still lags last year, down 2.8% to stand at 525mt, while cumulative sugar production totals 36mt, up 0.9% YoY.

Content Disclaimer

This publication has been prepared by ING solely for information purposes irrespective of a particular user's means, financial situation or investment objectives. The information does not constitute investment recommendation, and nor is it investment, legal or tax advice or an offer or solicitation to purchase or sell any financial instrument. Read more
